clinical_study.brief_title: Endocrine Changes and Their Correction in Heart and Lung Transplant Recipients and Donors
clinical_study.official_title: A Study of Endocrine Changes and Their Correction in Heart and Lung Transplant Recipients and Donors

lead_sponsor.agency: Semmelweis University Heart and Vascular Center

clinical_study.source: Semmelweis University Heart and Vascular Center

brief_summary.textblock:
The aim of this study is to assess the impact of endocrine changes and their correction on survival and organ fuction in heart and lung transplant recipients.This study also features an investigation of the hormone levels and hormonal replacement therapy of the donors to study it's role on the function of the transplanted hearts and lungs.
Thyroid hormones (TSH, thyroxine, tri-iodothyronin), cortisol and the antiduretic hormone will be studied.
The former two hormone levels will be defined in the recipients just before transplantation and three days later. In case of the donors all the three hormones will be recorded in time of the explantation. We would like to record the hormonal replacement therapy in all our patients as well to see it's effect on survival and on the transplantated organ function.
After the tranplantation during the hospital stay we record all the important hemodynamic, labratory paramaters, the result of the medical imagings, the medication, the length of ICU and hospital stay and the complications.
Recipients will be followed for five years. Organ function will be assessed every three month for a year, after than every six month for further four years. We would like to record the result of the cardiac echocardiographies, spirometries, imagings and the complications. Our purpose is to compare these results against the endocrine disorders and the replacement therapy.

study_pop.textblock: Patients undergoing heart or lung transplation and their organ donors.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients over 18 years of age admitted for heart or lung transplantation and their organ donors.
- written consent from the recipients
Exclusion Criteria:
- lack of consent
- non-evaluable patient due to insufficient clinical information
